subject: one-time setup
msgSnippet: Somehow, I was under the impression that each test in a test case started with a clean slate -- that the setup code was re-run for each test method. But that

Somehow, I was under the impression that each test
in a test case started with a "clean slate" -- that the
setup code was re-run for each test method.

But that doesn't appear to be the case. The test object
created during setup turned out to be reused for
subsequent tests in the test case, which caused problems
arising from old state, until I figured it out.

Now, for performance, it only makes sense that a fixture
would be reused for each test in a test case class. So I'm
not suggesting that the implementation is wrong.

But I read the docs at the main site, and I've been following
these threads for quite a while, and still I had a dead-wrong
impression of what's going on.

For example, in the FAQ, q2 "How do I use a text fixture?"
says:
   "Each test runs in its own test fixture to isolate tests from the
   changes made by other tests. Because the tests are isolated,
   they can be run in any order.... The JUnit framework
   automatically invokes the setUp() method before each test is
   run and the tearDown() method after each test is run."

Now for "test", I was reading "test *method*". As in testX(),
testY(). But my recent epiphany suggests that I should have
been reading it as "test *case*", as in "test-case class". And
since the example shows a single test case class, with multiple
test methods in it, it was easy to make that assumption.

Note:
In general, I'm not much fond of the name, "TestCase", because
to me that represents a single test. Since a TestCase class can
actually have multiple test methods, the name "TestFixture" is
probably more appropriate. But be that as it may...

It appears to me that the word "test" is badly overloaded in the
docs, meaning at various times, test method, test case, and
potentially even test suite.

The best way to eliminate confusion that I can see is to do a
global search on "test ", and replace with one of the hyphenated
words "test-method", "test-case", or "test-suite", as appropriate.
